choices.A: Only the io class is imported.
choices.B: All classes in the io package are imported.
choices.D: All classes in the io package and the subpackages of io packages, if any, are imported.
choices.C: All classes whose names start with io are imported.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct... and is missing one point in the question "What does import java.io.* mean ?"

choices.B: It is a marketing statement because Java programs must be compiled for a specific platform in order to run.
choices.C: Java programs can run on any Java Virtual Machine without being recompiled.
choices.D: Java programs, after being compiled, can run on any platform or device even without a Java Virtual Machine.
choices.A: Java programs are designed to run only in web browsers and, thus, can run wherever there is a browser.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of “write once, run anywhere” in Java?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
The correct answer is option D and E.

Selected Answer: E
E is the only correct answer, as it provides one member variable "private String name" and one method "public void display". 

D is not correct. It may look correct because of the member "private int num" but it's code enclosed in curly braces. There is no possibility to just dump a code block inside a class definition. It's a random code block containing "private int num", which is not correct itself also.
without reading the discussion, one could assume that all I had learned so far, were false.

Selected Answer: DE
D and E are correct
B is wrong because you can't declare package inside the class statement. D is correct because you can declare local variables inside a class statement, like methods (so E answer is correct aswell).

Almost every question with an incorrect answer. What's the catch?
